repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
When 'cython' is run specifying the -M command line option, the Cython.Build.Dependencies module is imported. This modules also contains support code to build Cython extensions via distutils or setuptools. Importing it fails when running with Python 3.12, where the distutils module has been removed.

Move one distutils import into the function that requires it. Handle one import error and re-implement the simple utility function that is required.

The Cython.Build module also re-exports the Cython.Distutils module. To preserve the exported API, the only sensible thing is to allow the corresponding import to fail when distutils is not present.

Fixes #5692.

comment_data.body: I wonder if we should print some sort of warning here. Just because we've changed the interface from what people expect. I know it'll always trigger on new versions of Python, but it's possible still worthwhile.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,2 +1,5 @@
 from .Dependencies import cythonize
-from .Distutils import build_ext
+try:
+    from .Distutils import build_ext
+except ModuleNotFoundError:
+    pass

comment_data.body: Without knowing why these symbols are re-exported here, ny reasoning for not adding a warning was that if someone is importing `build_ext` they are planning to use it with `distutils` or `setuptools` and in this case the import will succeed. A warning would trigger on completely unrelated code that happens to import anything from `Cython.Build` and the user has no way to silence the warning other than installing `setuptools`, which is what I'm trying to avoid having to do.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,2 +1,5 @@
 from .Dependencies import cythonize
-from .Distutils import build_ext
+try:
+    from .Distutils import build_ext
+except ModuleNotFoundError:
+    pass

comment_data.body: Since this is only an issue in Python 3.12, and Py3.7+ has module `__getattr__` ([PEP 562](https://peps.python.org/pep-0562/)), we could issue a warning when users access `build_ext` through this module. They should better go explicitly through `Cython.Distutils.build_ext` instead.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,2 +1,5 @@
 from .Dependencies import cythonize
-from .Distutils import build_ext
+try:
+    from .Distutils import build_ext
+except ModuleNotFoundError:
+    pass

comment_data.body: That's a good idea. I'll implement it. Cython is targeting Python >= 3.7, so I don't need to make the `__getattr__` conditional on the Python version. Should I?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,2 +1,5 @@
 from .Dependencies import cythonize
-from .Distutils import build_ext
+try:
+    from .Distutils import build_ext
+except ModuleNotFoundError:
+    pass

comment_data.body:
I've implemented it in https://github.com/cython/cython/commit/f39800c6d21c200fc664c56ec0c092663bb4e3b2
Sorry for not merging your PR. It was certainly a good starting point. Thanks for writing it up.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,2 +1,5 @@
 from .Dependencies import cythonize
-from .Distutils import build_ext
+try:
+    from .Distutils import build_ext
+except ModuleNotFoundError:
+    pass

@@ -1,2 +1,5 @@
 from .Dependencies import cythonize
-from .Distutils import build_ext
+try:
+    from .Distutils import build_ext
+except ModuleNotFoundError:
+    pass

comment_data.body: No problem. But I don't get the point of using the module level `__getattr__` if you don't emit a warning. Without warning the implementation is completely equivalent to the `try ... except ModuleNotFound` implementation I had here.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,2 +1,5 @@
 from .Dependencies import cythonize
-from .Distutils import build_ext
+try:
+    from .Distutils import build_ext
+except ModuleNotFoundError:
+    pass

comment_data.body:
> But I don't get the point of using the module level `__getattr__` if you don't emit a warning

Thing is, we don't currently have a replacement for Python 3.12. There, the import can still fail. But we are now using a lazy import, so the import of `build_ext` will only fail if explicitly requested, at the time when it's requested. And it might actually work, if setuptools has been imported then and replaces distutils.

We'll eventually have to fix up `cythonize()` for Python 3.12, at which point we have a reason to emit a warning. For now, we're not sure it's worth pointing users to something else which may or may not be better in the future.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,2 +1,5 @@
 from .Dependencies import cythonize
-from .Distutils import build_ext
+try:
+    from .Distutils import build_ext
+except ModuleNotFoundError:
+    pass

@@ -1,2 +1,5 @@
 from .Dependencies import cythonize
-from .Distutils import build_ext
+try:
+    from .Distutils import build_ext
+except ModuleNotFoundError:
+    pass

comment_data.body:
When I try it, I actually get a straight `ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'distutils.command.build_ext`. That's pretty clear, isn't it?

I agree that a hint how to resolve this would be nice, though not right here. It should go into `Cython.Distutils.build_ext`, where the `distutils` import is actually attempted. Thanks for the suggestion.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,2 +1,5 @@
 from .Dependencies import cythonize
-from .Distutils import build_ext
+try:
+    from .Distutils import build_ext
+except ModuleNotFoundError:
+    pass

comment_data.body:
> That's pretty clear, isn't it?

I don't know how widespread the knowledge that `setuptools` embeds a distribution of `distutils` is. I guess it is not obvious that this is the case, thus the suggestion about installing `setuptools` to solve the import error.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,2 +1,5 @@
 from .Dependencies import cythonize
-from .Distutils import build_ext
+try:
+    from .Distutils import build_ext
+except ModuleNotFoundError:
+    pass

@@ -1,2 +1,5 @@
 from .Dependencies import cythonize
-from .Distutils import build_ext
+try:
+    from .Distutils import build_ext
+except ModuleNotFoundError:
+    pass

commit.message:
Allow 'cython -M' to work without distutils installed

When 'cython' is run specifying the -M command line option, the
Cython.Build.Dependencies module is imported. This modules also
contains support code to build Cython extensions via distutils or
setuptools. Importing it fails when running with Python 3.12, where
the distutils module has been removed.

Move one distutils import into the function that requires it. Handle
one import error and re-implement the simple utility function that is
required.

The Cython.Build module also re-exports the Cython.Distutils module.
To preserve the exported API, the only sensible thing is to allow the
corresponding import to fail when distutils is not present.

Fixes #5692.
